maml:description.maml:para: Appends content of the PowerShell session's profile with an `Import-Module` statement.
Appends content of `$PROFILE` file (or content of `ProfilePath` parameter if is used) with an `Import-Module` statement that imports the module found with `Path`.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Content $PROFILE Import-Module C:\Users\Alice\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\posh-git\0.7.1\posh-git.psd1
PS C:\> Add-ModuleToProfile -Path C:\Users\Alice\PowerSploit PS C:\> Get-Content $PROFILE Import-Module C:\Users\Alice\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\posh-git\0.7.1\posh-git.psd1 Import-Module C:\Users\Alice\PowerSploit
PS C:\>

dev:remarks.maml:para: The module found in PowerSploit folder will have an `Import-Module` statement added to the default profile ($PROFILE) item.

maml:description.maml:para: The `Backups` object defined in `MK.PowerShell-config.json` will copy items to their destination location.

When called with the `Force` switch param, it will disregard `TurnOnBackup` and `BackupPolicy` object in `MK.PowerShell-config.json` and continue to attempt to backup sources that are define in `Backups` object.

`BackupPolicy` key is set to 'auto' by default and `TurnOnBackup` is set false. Ideally, when `TurnOnBackup` key is set to true prior to importing `MK.PowerShell.Flow`, this will be called and attempt to backup sources.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example enables `TurnOnBackup` and assigns one backup object to `Backups`. When `MK.PowerShell.Flow` imported next, it will attempt to overwrite the keybindings.json file if its in the `$Destination` folder. If there is no file in that folder it will simpily move it there. If `UpdatePolicy` had a value of `New`, it will move the file and to add an intger to its basename. For instance, for this example keybindings.json file will be keybindings(1).json.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates or updates help documentation files and module's README file. Also creates a XML based help documentation file for PowerShell.

With required `PlatyPS` (https://github.com/PowerShell/platyPS) module, this function will generate Markdown help documentation files (such as the file where you are reading this from)and update or create a README.md file with new functions from the help docs. Also this generates a new PowerShell help doc file that is used in the CLI.

maml:Description.maml:para: If the module is already imported, the value is the name of the module.
The name of the folder where PowerShell XML file will reside.
A relative path of module's folder where the Markdown files reside or will reside.
By default this function will re-import module to get the latest changes to that modules source code.
The name of the folder where PowerShell XML file will reside.
A relative path of module's folder where the Markdown files reside or will reside.
By default this function will re-import module to get the latest changes to that modules source code.
The name of the folder where PowerShell XML file will reside.
A relative path of module's folder where the Markdown files reside or will reside.
If the module is already imported, the value is the name of the module.
By default this function will re-import module to get the latest changes to that modules source code.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\Users\Alice\PowerSploit> Build-Documentation

dev:remarks.maml:para: Builds documentation for the PowerSploit module with default parameters.

maml:description.maml:para: With required `PlatyPS` (https://github.com/PowerShell/platyPS) module, calls [`New-MarkdownHelp`](https://github.com/PowerShell/platyPS/blob/master/docs/New-MarkdownHelp.md) or [`Update-MarkdownHelpModule`](https://github.com/PowerShell/platyPS/blob/master/docs/Update-MarkdownHelpModule.md).

If no Markdown files are in `MarkdownFolder`, this function will call `New-MarkdownHelp`. Else it will call `Update-MarkdownHelpModule`. After `New-MarkdownHelp` is executed it will iterate thru the newly Markdown files and add the online version url to file. This value, by default, is retrieved from a .git directory (if there is one) of the module.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the folder where PowerShell XML file will reside.
A relative path of module's folder where the Markdown files reside or will reside.
Prevents re-importing module prior to executing PlatyPS's `New-MarkdownHelp` or `Update-MarkdownHelpModule`.
If the module is already imported, the value is the name of the module.
The name of the folder where PowerShell XML file will reside.
A relative path of module's folder where the Markdown files reside or will reside.
Prevents re-importing module prior to executing PlatyPS's `New-MarkdownHelp` or `Update-MarkdownHelpModule`.
The name of the folder where PowerShell XML file will reside.
A relative path of module's folder where the Markdown files reside or will reside.
Prevents re-importing module prior to executing PlatyPS's `New-MarkdownHelp` or `Update-MarkdownHelpModule`.
The name of the folder where PowerShell XML file will reside.
A relative path of module's folder where the Markdown files reside or will reside.
If the module is already imported, the value is the name of the module.
Prevents re-importing module prior to executing PlatyPS's `New-MarkdownHelp` or `Update-MarkdownHelpModule`.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Build-PlatyPSMarkdown -Path C:\Users\Alice\PowerSploit -NoReImportModule

dev:remarks.maml:para: With specified `Path` value and `NoReImportModule` switched, this will generate (new or update) files for PowerSploit module. The `NoReImportModule` prevents re-importing PowerSploit so the current state of this imported module is used. In otherwords, if changes to the source code of PowerSploit has been made it will not be available until it is imported again. And because of that `NoReImportModule` is typically not switched.

maml:description.maml:para: With `InputObject` tested for equality via `-eq`, will `Write-Output` `Value` only when equality operator returns `true`.
{{Fill in the Description}}

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $LifeEvents += (Get-Date) -ge (Get-Date -Year 2061) | ConvertTo-EnumFlag -Value ([CosmicEvents]::WatchHalley)

dev:remarks.maml:para: The `-ge` assertation will pipe a bool value in `ConvertTo-EnumFlag` which will increment `$LifeEvents` with `[CosmicEvents]::WatchHalley` if the assertation is `true`. If the piped value is `false`, `ConvertTo-EnumFlag` will `Write-Output` with `0`.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a valid path from a parent of one of its children which overlaps that parent's path.
In set-theory this will be considered a relative complement. That is the directories in ChildPath that are not in Path.

A diagram to illustrate what is mentioned above: A = C:\Windows\diagnostics\system B = .\diagnostics\system\Keyboard\en-US\CL_LocalizationData.psd1 B\A = .\Keyboard\en-US\CL_LocalizationData.psd1 R = C:\Windows\diagnostics\system\Keyboard\en-US\CL_LocalizationData.psd1
The path 'R' is what will be returned if -IsValid is not switched otherwise $true will be returned.

maml:Description.maml:para: Parent path of $ChildPath. This can be relative.
Returns true if function found a complement folder. False is returned if no complement was found.
Parent path of $ChildPath. This can be relative.
Returns true if function found a complement folder. False is returned if no complement was found.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
E:\Temp\AIT\> Get-MergedPath E:\Temp\AIT\resources\ -ChildPath .\resources\android\AiT-Feature.jpg E:\Temp\AIT\resources\android\AiT-Feature.jpg
E:\Temp\AIT\> Get-MergedPath E:\Temp\AIT\resources\ -ChildPath .\resources\android\AiT-Feature.jpg -IsValid True

dev:remarks.maml:para: Demonstration of using Get-MergedPath with truthly values

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: E:\Temp\AIT\> Get-MergedPath E:\Temp\AIT\resources\ -ChildPath .\reWWWources\android\AiT-Feature.jpg E:\Temp\AIT\> Get-MergedPath E:\Temp\AIT\resources\ -ChildPath .\reWWWources\android\AiT-Feature.jpg -IsValid False

dev:remarks.maml:para: Demonstration of using Get-MergedPath with falsely values

maml:description.maml:para: Outputs information about a module with given name or path.

Valid `Path` parameter values are to a manifest (.psd1) file, module (.psm1) file and root module directory. And valid `Name` parameter values are constricted to modules installed locally. With those possible values information about the module with be returned.

maml:Description.maml:para: A dynamic parameter with its valid set being confined to locally installed modules.
Valid values are to a manifest (.psd1) file, module (.psm1) file and root module directory.
A dynamic parameter with its valid set being confined to locally installed modules.
Valid values are to a manifest (.psd1) file, module (.psm1) file and root module directory.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-MKModuleInfo -Name Plaster
Name : Plaster Path : E:\Plaster\Release\Plaster PathFolderName : Plaster ManifestFilePath : E:\Plaster\Release\Plaster\Plaster.psd1 RootModuleFilePath : E:\Plaster\Release\Plaster\Plaster.psm1 Version : 1.1.4

dev:remarks.maml:para: With Plaster being installed locally, it is valid value in the parameter set.

maml:description.maml:para: Scaffolds files based on the required Plaster (https://github.com/PowerShell/Plaster)template.

When `PlasterTemplatePath` is set to a Plaster template, this script will inspect the template for variables that will become additional parameters. Those variables must be in the form of the Plaster style variables. For an example: 'PLASTER_PARAM_CongruentPath', where 'CongruentPath' is the variable that will appear as an additional parameter.
If calling this method by script and not thru the CLI, positional binding is enabled so that can be done.

maml:Description.maml:para: A path value to a Plaster template (manifest) file.
A path value to a Plaster template (manifest) file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Install-Template -PlasterTemplatePath 'C:\Users\Alice\PlasterTemplates\NewMVC\plasterManifest_en-US.xml' -AppName 'CoffeeApp'

dev:remarks.maml:para: One can deduce that the variable 'PLASTER_PARAM_AppName' is in the template file, which is used in this example to assign a name value to the app being scaffold.

maml:description.maml:para: Streamlines publishing a module using `Publish-Module`.

When `MK.PowerShell-config.json` has valid `NuGetApiKey`, it will deploy locally module to a temp folder, removing specified items via `Exclude`, prompt user to confirm publishing and will "teardown" setup items after confirming.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates root-module and manifest file with commands to be exported.

When called, it will search for .ps1 files in the `SourceDirectory` and update the root module with `using module` statements with the files it has found. If anywhere in the file a `# NoExport: <Command>` comment is found, it will omit that command from being listed in the manifest file. Also all commands that are intended to be exported must follow the PowerShell convention of `<verb>-<noun>`.
